Emergency_Advice: CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation): For adults, perform 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths. For infants and children, the ratio of compressions to breaths may vary. AED (Automated External Defibrillator): Use an AED if available and trained to do so.

Apply Pressure: Use a clean cloth or bandage to apply direct pressure to the wound. Elevate: Raise the injured part above the level of the heart if possible. Use a Tourniquet: As a last resort, apply a tourniquet if the bleeding is severe and cannot be controlled by direct pressure.

Cool the Burn: Run cool (not cold) water over the burn for at least 10 minutes. Cover the Burn: Use a clean, non-stick dressing or cloth. Do Not Break Blisters: Leave blisters intact to avoid infection.
Immobilize: Keep the injured area still using a splint or sling. Avoid Movement: Do not move the person if you suspect a spinal injury.
Heimlich Maneuver: Perform abdominal thrusts to dislodge the object. Back Blows: For infants, alternate between back blows and chest thrusts.
Lay the Person Down: Keep them flat on their back. Elevate Legs: Raise the legs about 12 inches if there are no injuries that would be worsened by this. Keep Warm: Use blankets to maintain body heat.
Assist with Medication: Help the person use their prescribed inhaler. Calm the Person: Keep them calm and in an upright position.
Use an EpiPen: If the person has an epinephrine auto-injector, assist them in using it. Call for Help: Seek emergency medical assistance immediately.
Protect from Injury: Remove nearby dangerous objects. Do Not Restrain: Let the seizure run its course. Turn on Side: After the seizure, turn the person onto their side to keep the airway clear.

Identify the Poison: Try to determine what was ingested. Call Poison Control: Contact the local poison control center or emergency services. Do Not Induce Vomiting: Unless instructed by a professional.
Rinse with Water: Use clean water to flush out any foreign objects. Cover the Eye: Use a clean cloth or eye patch to protect the injured eye.
Move to a Cool Place: Get the person out of the heat. Hydrate: Provide cool water to drink if the person is conscious. Cool the Body: Use cool, wet cloths or a cool bath to lower body temperature.

Ice: Apply an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to the affected area for 15-20 minutes every hour. This helps reduce swelling.
Compression: Use an elastic bandage to wrap the injured area, providing support and reducing swelling. Be careful not to wrap too tightly.
Elevation: Keep the injured limb elevated above heart level to help reduce swelling.

Get the Person Out of Water: Safely bring the person to shore or out of the pool, if possible.
Check for Breathing: If the person is not breathing, begin CPR immediately.
For adults: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute and give rescue breaths (30 compressions to 2 breaths).
For children: Start with 5 initial rescue breaths before starting compressions.
Seek Professional Medical Help: Continue CPR until professional help arrives or the person starts breathing independently.

Lay the Person Down: Position the person flat on their back with legs elevated to improve blood flow to the brain.
Loosen Tight Clothing: Remove or loosen any tight clothing or accessories.
Check for Breathing: Ensure the person is breathing. If not, call emergency services and begin CPR.
Give Fresh Air: Ensure the area is well-ventilated and avoid overcrowding around the person.
Stay with the Person: Monitor their condition until they regain consciousness. Seek medical help if they don’t recover quickly or have a history of fainting.

Stay Calm: Keep the person calm and sitting upright.
Lean Forward: Have the person lean forward slightly to prevent swallowing blood.
Pinch the Nose: Use your thumb and index finger to pinch the nostrils shut, applying pressure for about 10 minutes.
Apply a Cold Compress: Place a cold compress or ice pack on the bridge of the nose to help constrict blood vessels.
Seek Medical Attention: If the bleeding continues for more than 20 minutes or is severe, seek medical assistance.
Move to a Warm Place: Get the person out of the cold. Warm the Body: Use blankets and warm (not hot) drinks to raise body temperature. Avoid Direct Heat: Do not use hot water or direct heat sources.
Administer Sugar: Give a sugary drink or snack if the person is conscious and able to swallow. Monitor Condition: If there's no improvement, seek medical help.

Keep the Person Still: Have them lie down with their head and shoulders slightly elevated.
Apply Ice: Use an ice pack wrapped in a cloth on any bumps or bruises to reduce swelling.
Monitor for Symptoms: Watch for signs of concussion such as dizziness, confusion, nausea, or headaches. Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.
